title: New laws to end early retirement rip-off
text:
13,500.00 -550.00 
David Cameron accuses pension companies of exploiting the Government's pension reforms by trying to create a 'new way of charging people' 
Savers will be protected from "rip off" exit fees for cashing in their pensions early with a new legally enforced cap under plans outlined by David Cameron on Thursday. 
The Prime Minister will accuse the industry of exploiting the government's "once in a generation" pension reforms by trying to create a "new way of charging people". 
He will announce new plans to end exit penalties worth up to 20 per cent of the value of people's savings which are being charged when they withdraw money from their pensions in their fifties and sixties. 
David Cameron will accuse pensions industry of exploiting the government's pension reforms 
The Telegraph understands that new legislation could be introduced to cap the penalties at no more than 2.5 per cent. 
Whitehall sources also said the Government will also begin making inquiries into a broad range of rip-offs hitting savers trying to use the new pension freedoms. 
As part of a campaign to end poor treatment, The Telegraph has published evidence that savers are being blocked from using their funds like bank accounts in retirement and charged excessive annual management fees. 
Speaking ahead of the launch of an official consultation, Mr Cameron said: "Our pension reforms were the biggest in a generation and they offer people much greater choice on how to use their hard earned savings. 
"The aim has always been to give people more control over their money, not to create a new way of charging people. 
"That's why we're launching this consultation because we want to ensure that pension providers are not using exit charges and restrictions as a barrier to switching just when the Government is providing pensioners with greater freedoms." 
• Move out of your big homes and help society, minister tells over-55s 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) rules on April 6 ended the need for savers to turn their pensions into a lifetime "annuity" income. The over-55s were told they would be able to take out as much of their money as often as they liked. 
But a series of disclosures by The Telegraph over the past two months have shown how millions of people have found accessing their retirement funds more difficult than the Government had advertised. 
Some middle-class pensioners are losing as much as £10,000 over their retirements because of high charges, while others are being refused partial withdrawals of their pension pots. 
The consultation document asks for information about whether there is cause for greater intervention by the Government on such matters. 
Around one in 10 savers faces fees if they withdraw their pensions before a specific retirement date, which will have been agreed when they were sold the policy. 
Many are finding they cannot access their money until age 65 without losing a large portion of the fund. In the worst cases, the cash is locked away until age 75. 
Most of those close to retirement face just a small fee of 1 per cent or 2 per cent. Those further away, perhaps aged 55 with a retirement age of 75, can lose as much as a fifth of the fund to the penalties, experts say. 
• Tax relief on pensions may not be scrapped, George Osborne says 
Industry figures passed to The Telegraph indicate that a cap could be set at around 2.5 per cent. Insurers believe that just 5 per cent of those with an exit penalty would face fees above this level, and so would be more open to a cap. 
The Government is understood to have been given this information in private, but is not expected to specify the level of a new cap in until the consultation is complete. 
Alongside exit fees, the consultation paper will also look at making it easier to transfer pensions between different schemes and ensuring that there is "greater clarity" surrounding financial advice. 
Malcolm McLean, a senior consultant at pension administrators Barnett Waddingham, said: "Many of the old 'legacy' pension schemes are trapping people into an arrangement that they simply cannot get out of in an economical way - and in many cases the penalties people face are an absolute rip-off." 
• George Osborne must be truly radical if he is to fix Britain’s broken pensions 
"The inability to transfer out of poor-value pensions has been an issue for a long time. The industry clearly hasn't found it possible to sort itself out and so the Government has been left with little option but to step in." 
A Downing Street spokeswoman said: "Our reforms have already proved extremely popular and are giving people real flexibility over their pensions savings for the first the time. 
"But it is not on that some people are missing out on that freedom because of expensive fees and other barriers that are blocking them from accessing their own money. 
“Our message is clear: the industry must sort this out or we will take action to guarantee people that freedom."
